Description: Base Ring I pottery jug; hand-made; globular-ovoid body on a ring base; tall narrow neck, tapering outwards towards the top, with an everted rim; single strap handle from shoulder to mid-neck; double ridge at the junction of handle and neck; a single ridge defines the junction of body and neck; plastic decoration on the body below the shoulder; made of orange-red clay differentially fired red on the body and black on the shoulder and neck; highly burnished, metallic surface; vase complete but repaired from fragments.
Curator's comments: This type of imported pottery (see Merrillees 1968) was copied in faience, glass and travertine/calcite by Egyptian artisans (Karageorghis and Merrillees 2007). Bibliography W.V. Davies (ed.) Egypt and Africa (1991) [pl.6,2] V. Karageorghis and R.S. Merrillees 2007, 'Imitations of Late Cypriote pottery found in Egypt', Report of the Department of Antiquities, Cyprus (Nicosia, 2007), 145-155. R.S. Merrillees, The Cypriote Bronze Age pottery found in Egypt. SIMA XVIII (Lund, 1968). R.S. Merrillees, 'The Cypriote Base-Ring jug from Saqqara' in P. Åström (ed.) The chronology of Base-Ring ware and Bichrome Wheel-made ware (Stockholm, 2001), 23-30.
